context: However, due to its poor stability, the HO° concentration in water is usually low (in the range 10−10 to 10−12 M) which counterbalances its high reactivity. Consequently, using AOPs, the HO° formation is mostly the rate-limiting step (Beltrán, 1997). In the peroxone process (O3/H2O2), HO° are involved in a chain cycle (Glaze and Kang, 1989; Acero and Von Gunten, 2000) which is initiated by the fast decomposition of dissolved ozone by the hydroperoxide anion  HO 2 - (Staehelin and Hoigne, 1982, 1985; Buehler et al., 1984; Staehelin et al., 1984), the conjugated base of H2O2 (pKa=11.8): (1) H 2 O - + O 3 → k 1 =× 10 6 M - 1 s - 1 O 2 + HO ° + O 2 ° - The application of the peroxone process in a continuous operation showed that dimethyldisulfide (DMDS) mass transfer was improved when ozone was previously dissolved at pH 8 in water and mixed with a solution of hydrogen peroxide directly in the scrubber (Biard et al., 2009a). The peroxone process was more efficient than a simple ozonation only when a restrictive H2O2-to-O3 inlet concentrations ratio ( F H 2 O 2 / F O 3 ) ranging between 1 and 2molmol−1 was implemented. These observations demonstrated that both direct (molecular ozone attack) and indirect reactions (HO°, generated by O3 decomposition, attack) were potentially involved in the mechanism. Toward a deeper description and comprehension of the transfer mechanisms, which could enable to generalise these results to other VOCs, several information were missing.

The efficiency of this process is influenced by the ratio of H2O2 to O3, highlighting its critical role in enhancing the reaction mechanisms involved in pollutant degradation. The relationship is characterized by H2O2's function as a reactant that facilitates the formation of reactive species necessary for the process to occur effectively.
